channel.title: Comments on: WGW 34: The Value of Repetition

item.title: By: I said I’d post every WHAT? |
item.dc:creator: I said I’d post every WHAT? |
item.description: […] kidding.  It’s a good topic, but I’d be totally cribbing offa Bengozen, who wrote a personal and heartfelt post about a very similar subject in his Weekly Go Wednesday. Really I’m going to write about how […]
item.content:encoded: […] kidding.  It’s a good topic, but I’d be totally cribbing offa Bengozen, who wrote a personal and heartfelt post about a very similar subject in his Weekly Go Wednesday. Really I’m going to write about how […]

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Agreed. I can definitely say that I've made the mistake of just quickly overviewing books. The advice by the dan / professional players is definitely great to keep in mind. Thanks for sharing!
item.content:encoded: Agreed. I can definitely say that I’ve made the mistake of just quickly overviewing books. The advice by the dan / professional players is definitely great to keep in mind. Thanks for sharing!

item.title: By: Claude
item.dc:creator: Claude
item.description: I agree with you. Better to go slowly and repeatedly to acquire a solid foundation. Quick overview of books leads to nothing. This is what strong players say. A strong French player of Japanese descent (8d) recommends reading the books at least 10 times before understanding something. Another player, Chinese (8d-2p), emphasizes the very gradual acquisition by repetition. But it is very tempting to cut corners!!
item.content:encoded:
I agree with you. Better to go slowly and repeatedly to acquire
a solid foundation. Quick overview of books leads to nothing. This is what strong
players say. A strong French player of Japanese descent (8d) recommends reading
the books at least 10 times before understanding something. Another player,
Chinese (8d-2p), emphasizes the very gradual acquisition by repetition. But it
is very tempting to cut corners!!

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Thanks Claude! I'm glad that I can be of help on your journey to gain another stone. Please let me know if you ever have any questions or if I can be of any assistance in another way.
item.content:encoded: Thanks Claude! I’m glad that I can be of help on your journey to gain another stone. Please let me know if you ever have any questions or if I can be of any assistance in another way.

item.title: By: Claude
item.dc:creator: Claude
item.description: Hi Ben, congrats for your blog which helps me to continue in my efforts to study this really difficult game. Regards.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Glad you enjoyed it! I've been reading it here and there as well and I'm always surprised at how much I enjoy it every time. =) Hope I'll catch you online later!
item.content:encoded: Glad you enjoyed it! I’ve been reading it here and there as well and I’m always surprised at how much I enjoy it every time. =) Hope I’ll catch you online later!

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Haha. When I'm a solid dan player, maybe I'll admit to having a sort of decent reading ability. xD Otherwise, got a long way to go! =)
item.content:encoded: Haha. When I’m a solid dan player, maybe I’ll admit to having a sort of decent reading ability. xD Otherwise, got a long way to go! =)

item.description: "Poor reading ability???" You??? Ben, I think that you need to take a break... :)

item.title: By: Eyecatcher
item.dc:creator: Eyecatcher
item.description: Soo true, in the last couple of days i thought about reading "Lessons in the Fundemantals of Go" again =) Now with your post, i think i definitely will. Thanks for the nice post.
item.content:encoded: Soo true, in the last couple of days i thought about reading “Lessons in the Fundemantals of Go” again =) Now with your post, i think i definitely will. Thanks for the nice post.
